title: Need recommendations...
content:
I’m doing a redesign of a package for Peppermint bonbons.  
I’m stuck with the choice of typography that will be used for small (5pt) text (product description and list of ingredients and usual stuff ).

Little bit about design that might help narrow down the list of choices...  
whole design will have \*retro\* (something like Penguin peppermints) feel. Main headline is set in Neutra and another one with Fayette.

What i need is good Readability at such small sizes. (I’m must say I prefere san serif face, tho I’m open to suggestions).

Thanks,

L.

 [‹ Need information about Chicken Plain Font !!!!](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/typophile.com/node/17214 "Go to previous forum topic") [Yet another Van Doesburg? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/typophile.com/node/17368 "Go to next forum topic")
author: luka

comments.content: [Bell Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/bell-gothic/) (or better & more recently — [Bell Centennial](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/bell-centennial/)) was desgined for use in telephone books at tiny sizes. Not sure how compatible it will be with your overall design, but should prove to be readable.

Oddly enough [Copperplate](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/copperplate/ef-medium/opentype-ps/196015/) style type was frequently used to set tiny “boiler plate” text generally seen at the bottom of contracts, warranties, etc.

Now it may seem odd that small caps were used as such, but it was common practice up through the mid-1940s.

Engelhardt’s suggestion is right on with Bell for both the era and use. If that doesn’t jive, try [Amplitude](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=amplitude).

BTW, haven’t seen Fayette. Can you show us?

Is this the Fayette you’re using?

Hi!

I need similar recommendations.

I’m looking for a typeface for use with 5pt text on ice cream packages. The problem is, that it needs to support **estonian, latvian, lithuanian, cyrillic, swedish and english**. Actually cyrillic might be from a different typeface but other languages should look the same.

Currently i’m using an opentype version of Arial [:(] , because it’s the only font i’ve found that has all the characters i need. Unfortunately, it’s not very economical.

Most of the packages are printed using Flexo technology, which means that dot gain is quite big.

Thanks in advance

v2rv:

I used for a similar project Myriad Pro. It is a clear sans and has all the characters (and I happened to own it...), not very scientific, I know

[FF DIN Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=FF.11554.0.0), [FF Meta Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=meta%20pro), and [FF Dax Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&searchstr=dax%20pro) are OpenType fonts that contain all those character sets in a single font file and should serve well at 5 pt.

Setting very gainy 5pt text requires special attention,  
and I don’t think things like Meta and Dax will cut it.  
Even something as brutish as Adsans\* would serve better,  
while Parable for example would be more refined.

\* [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/adsans/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071222004916/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/adsans/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/adsans/")

Somebody needs to make a list of lo-fi fonts.
